### Democracy Can't Fix This

Lots of people think we can fix this simply by electing better leaders. But what lots of people don't realize is that democracy is basically just theatre at this point.

Princeton University did a study. They analyzed 1,779 policy decisions over 20 years. The correlation between what you want and what happens?

**Zero. Percent.**

Not low. Not small. ZERO.

But when economic elites want something? They get it 78% of the time.

You have the same political influence as your houseplant. Actually less, at least politicians pretend to care about the environment.

Your "representative" has 750,000 constituents. You get 0.00013% of their attention. They spend 70% of their time fundraising from rich people who aren't you.

The math that matters:

- 0% correlation between public preference and policy outcomes
- 78% correlation when economic elites want something
- Translation: You're not a citizen. You're a spectator with a ballot.

Professors Martin Gilens and Benjamin Page analyzed over two decades of data to answer a fundamental question: **Does the government represent the people?**

After examining nearly 2,000 public opinion surveys and comparing them to actual policy outcomes, they discovered that the opinions of [90% of Americans have virtually no impact on legislation](https://www.cambridge.org/core/services/aop-cambridge-core/content/view/62327F513959D0A304D4893B382B992B/S1537592714001595a.pdf/testing_theories_of_american_politics_elites_interest_groups_and_average_citizens.pdf).

In a representative democracy, the more people like a bill, the more likely it would be to become law.

![](assets/bill-public-support-vs-chance-of-adoption-true-democracy.png)

However, in reality, public support has almost no influence on what laws are passed. Whether there is [0% or 100%](https://www.cambridge.org/core/services/aop-cambridge-core/content/view/62327F513959D0A304D4893B382B992B/S1537592714001595a.pdf/testing_theories_of_american_politics_elites_interest_groups_and_average_citizens.pdf) support for a policy, there's a [30% likelihood](https://www.cambridge.org/core/services/aop-cambridge-core/content/view/62327F513959D0A304D4893B382B992B/S1537592714001595a.pdf/testing_theories_of_american_politics_elites_interest_groups_and_average_citizens.pdf) that it will become law.

![](assets/bill-public-support-vs-chance-of-adoption-what-actually-happens.png)

So voting won't fix this. Neither will protests. The system is designed to ignore you.

This isn't cynicism. It's math. You live in an oligarchy with democracy cosplay.

But there's another way to change the world: **Make doing the right thing more profitable than doing the wrong thing.**
